Title: Three Body Problem
Description: In this simulation we take a look at an example of the three body problem! This is fascinating problem within physics that can teach us an awful lot about how nature deals with complex multi-body systems. During this lesson we will discuss one of the most popular solutions to the three body problem which resembles a figure of eight!

LessonPages.Text:
The three-body problem provides a fascinating example of orbital mechanics. The problem arises when trying to come up with a set of velocities and positions for three bodies of equal mass that results in a stable, non-chaotic system. 

The simulation here is a crude-replica of the well-known "figure of eight" solution to the three-body problem.

To better visualize this set the trail length to the maximum setting of '2000'. Additionally, use the shortcut Ctrl-O to toggle the future projected orbits of the three bodies. Note the rough outline of the orbital trails matches that of a figure of eight. Of course, even this system will become unstable over time, but for the sake of fun let's accelerate the process. 

See the next page for instructions.

Step #1: pause the simulation via the button or the shortcut Ctrl-P. 
Step #2: activate 'Edit Mode' (the appropriate button is highlighted).
Step #3: select 'Body 1'.
Step #4: select 'Edit Body Properties'.
Step #5: change the mass from 60,000,000 to 80,000,000.
Step #6: click 'Confirm'.
Step #7: resume the simulation.

Behold as the once delicate arrangement of three bodies has begun to destabilize! 

But, you may be wondering if there are any natural examples of the three body problem: there are, but perhaps not in the way you expect. Rather than finely tuned, deterministic systems, nature solves the three body problem by well, cheating.

(see the next page)

Essentially, in multi-star systems it is common to find a single star orbiting around two other stars that are much closer together. Due to their relative proximity, these two close stars form a common barycentre which the third star orbits as if it were a single body.
